arguments.argument: Subsidies make EVs more affordable for average consumers.
They accelerate the transition to cleaner transportation.
Electric vehicles help reduce air pollution and emissions.
Subsidies support growth in the domestic EV industry.
They create green jobs in manufacturing and tech.
Incentives drive innovation in battery and charging tech.
They help the U.S. compete with global EV leaders.
Public investment reduces long-term healthcare costs from pollution.
Subsidies encourage infrastructure development for EVs.
They level the playing field against fossil fuel industry subsidies.
Subsidies distort market competition and consumer choice.
Most benefits go to wealthier consumers who can afford EVs.
Government funds should support broader public transportation.
The EV industry should stand on its own without aid.
Battery production has its own environmental concerns.
Not all regions have the infrastructure to support EVs yet.
Subsidy programs can be inefficient and poorly targeted.
They may encourage overproduction before the grid is ready.
It's unfair to force all taxpayers to fund private vehicle purchases.
Used EV markets are not yet mature, limiting long-term value.
